subtopic: General Technology,Transport Security,Educational Technology and Distance Education,Information and Records Management,Information Technology
subsc:
(Historic)Primary health, including
            reproductive health, child health and health
trustfund: TF021245-MALI: STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT,TF020805-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Population Project for India aims to
            develop a comprehensive family planning program in select
            districts (six in Uttar Pradesh and six in Mysore State)
            covering a total population of about 20 million persons. The
            project will consist of three components. The first will
            provide family planning services through an Urban Program
            focusing on post-partum motivation and service; an Optimal
            Government of India Program to implement the
            Government's pattern in the twelve districts; and an
            Intensive Rural Program to include a focus on
            recently-delivered mothers in rural areas. The second
            component will consist of two new Population Centers in
            Lucknow and Bangalore to be primarily responsible for the
            management information system and training. The system would
            monitor progress in project areas, evaluate performance, and
            recommend changes that would be relevant to other parts of
            India. The third  component consists of a variety of
            physical facilities and equipment, including: the two
            Population Centers and nine District Family Planning
            Bureaus; two Regional Family Planning Centers; two maternity
            hospitals; ten maternity-sterilization wards; sixteen
            Maternity Homes and fourteen Urban Family Welfare Centers;
            complete Primary Health Centers consisting of a dispensary,
            family planning clinic, and staff living quarters for health
            and family planning personnel; subcenters for assistant
            nurse-midwives and family welfare workers; and fourteen
            assistant nurse-midwife schools. This document reports the
            results of a preappraisal mission which visited India from
            July 13 to August 21, 1970. The mission found that while the
            achievements of the Indian Government's program were
            considerable, the program is not functioning as well as it
            should or could. The project will establish the base for
            continuing assessment of the program with opportunities for
            variation and experimentation, thus providing in the longer
            term a valuable tool for improvement of the performance of
            the whole program.
